text: Departement Informatik Wintersession 2021 Prof. Ueli Maurer Exam Diskrete Mathematik 5. Februar 2021 Hinweise: 1.) Erlaubte Hilfsmittel: Selbstverfasste, handgeschriebene Notizen auf 6 A4-Seiten. Es ist erlaubt ein Wörterbuch zu benutzen. Es sind keine weiteren Hilfsmittel erlaubt (auch kein Taschenrechner). 2.) Die Prüfung besteht aus 4 Aufgaben mit total 115 Punkten. Die Aufgaben sind in drei Schwierigkeitsstufen von (⋆) bis (⋆ ⋆ ⋆) eingeteilt. 3.) Die Aufgaben sind direkt auf dem Prüfungsblatt zu lösen. Bei Platzmangel beﬁnden sich am Ende der Prüfung vier Zusatzblätter. Weitere Zusatzblätter können während der Prüfung bei uns bezogen werden. Nur von uns verteilte Zusatzblätter sind erlaubt. 4.) Bitte verwenden Sie einen dokumentenechten Stift (also keinen Bleistift) und nicht die Farben Rot oder Grün. 5.) Bitte legen Sie die Legi für die Ausweiskontrolle auf den Tisch. 6.) Sie dürfen bis 10 Minuten vor Ende der Prüfung vorzeitig abgeben und den Raum still verlassen. 7.) Mobiltelefone und Smartwatches müssen komplett ausgeschaltet sein (kein Standby) und dürfen nicht am Körper getragen werden. Prüfungs-Nr. Sets, Relations and Functions . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 32 Points a) Short Questions. Each correct answer gives one point. No justiﬁcation is required. (10 Points) 1.) List the elements of the set {0, 1} × {(0, 1)}. 2.) List the elements of the set (∅ ∪ {∅}) ∩ {∅, {∅}}. 3.) How many elements has the set P({∅, {∅}, ∅}∪{{∅}, {{∅}}})? 4.) For any set A and any relation ρ on A we have idA ⊆ ρ ⇐⇒ idA ⊆ ̂ρ. 2 True 2 False 5.) The composition of two symmetric relations is symmetric. 2 True 2 False 6.) The union of two transitive relations is transitive. 2 True 2 False 7.) The complement of an irreﬂexive relation is reﬂexive. 2 True 2 False 8.) Find a set A and a function f : A → A such that f is injective but not surjective. 9.) The power set of the set of all prime numbers is countable. 2 True 2 False 10.) For all n ∈ N, the set (Q[x])n is countable. 2 True 2 False b) Prove or disprove: The poset ({2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9}; |) is a lattice. (2 Points) Page 2 of 21 c) (⋆ ⋆) Let (A; ≼) be a poset and deﬁne the relation ≺ on A by a ≺ b def ⇐⇒ a ≼ b ∧ a ̸= b for all (a, b) ∈ A × A. Prove that ≺ is transitive. (5 Points) Page 3 of 21 d) We want to deﬁne the integers Z based on the natural numbers N. In order to do this, we let A def = N × N and think of an element (a, b) ∈ A as a representation of the integer that is the diﬀerence of a and b. 1.) (⋆) Find an equivalence relation ∼ on A which captures that two representations correspond to the same integer, i.e., allowing us to deﬁne Z def = A/∼ . Use only addition (and no minus sign −) in N. No justiﬁcation is required. (1 Point) 2.) (⋆) Deﬁne the sum of two representations of integers as a function sum : A2 → A, only using addition (and no minus sign −) in N. No justiﬁcation is required. (1 Point) 3.) (⋆ ⋆) A function f : B2 → B is called θ-consistent for an equivalence relation θ on B if (b1 θ b ′ 1 and b2 θ b ′ 2) =⇒ f (b1, b2) θ f (b ′ 1, b ′ 2) is true for all b1, b2, b′ 1, b′ 2 ∈ B. Prove that sum is ∼-consistent (for the choices of ∼ and sum of the previous subtasks). Make sure that no minus sign − occurs in your proof. (6 Points) Page 4 of 21 e) (⋆ ⋆ ⋆) Prove or disprove: The set S = { a ∈ N∞ | ∀i ∈ N ∃j ∈ N (i < j ∧ aj = 2 ai )} is countable. (7 Points) Hint: Recall that N∞ is the set of all semi-inﬁnite sequences over N. Moreover, for any a ∈ N∞ and any i ∈ N, ai is the natural number at the i-th position of a. Hint: The sequence 20, 21, 22, 23, . . . is an element of S. Page 5 of 21 Task 2. No justiﬁcation is required. (5 Points) 1.) Compute R31(3131310333131313131318). 2.) Compute R12345(12344(12345123451234512345)). 3.) Compute gcd(284, 384). 4.) Find x ∈ Z13 such that 4x ≡13 1. 5.) There exists x ∈ Z137875 such that 256x ≡137875 1. 2 True 2 False b) (⋆) We have generated the RSA public key (n, e) = (15, 3). 1.) Encrypt the message m = 4 under the public key (n, e). (1 Point) 2.) Find the secret key d that corresponds to the public key (n, e). (2 Points) 3.) The ciphertext y = 7 was encrypted with the public key (n, e). Decrypt it. (1 Point) c) (⋆) Alice and Bob execute the Diﬃe-Hellman protocol using the subgroup of ⟨Z∗ 15; ⊙⟩ that is generated by g = 2. Alice sends the message yA = 8. They agree on the secret key kAB = 2. (3 Points) What message did Bob send? Calculation. You will get full points if the answer above is correct. Otherwise, you may get partial points for the calculation in this box. Page 6 of 21 d) (⋆ ⋆) Let m, n ∈ N \ {0, 1} and consider the function f : Zmn → Zm × Zn with f (x) = (Rm(x), Rn(x)) for all x ∈ Zmn. Prove that if f is injective then gcd(m, n) = 1. (6 Points) Page 7 of 21 Task 3. Algebra . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 30 Points a) Short Questions. Each correct answer gives one point. No justiﬁcation is required. (5 Points) 1.) Every group of order 17 has 16 generators. 2 True 2 False 2.) How many zerodivisors has Z91? (Hint: 91 = 7 · 13) 3.) Find a ﬁeld with 27 elements. 4.) Compute (2x + 2) · (2x + 1) in Z3[x]x2+1. 5.) List all irreducible monic polynomials of degree 2 in Z2[x]. b) (⋆) Consider the algebra ⟨Z; ⋆⟩ where ⋆ is deﬁned by a ⋆ b def = a3 + b3 for any a, b ∈ Z. Decide whether ⟨Z; ⋆⟩ is a monoid, a group or neither. Prove your answer. (3 Points) Page 8 of 21 c) (⋆) Let ⟨R; +, −, 0, ·, 1⟩ be a ring and let a, b ∈ R. Use only the ring axioms and the fact that 0x = x0 = 0 for all x ∈ R to prove that (−a)b = a(−b). (6 Points) Page 9 of 21 d) (⋆ ⋆) Prove or disprove: If for a ﬁnite ﬁeld F two polynomials p(x) ∈ F [x] and q(x) ∈ F [x] correspond to the same function (i.e., p(a) = q(a) for all a ∈ F ), then they are the same polynomial. (4 Points) Page 10 of 21 e) (⋆ ⋆) Find an isomorphism between the groups ⟨Z3; ⊕⟩ × ⟨Z35; ⊕⟩ and ⟨Z21; ⊕⟩ × ⟨Z5; ⊕⟩. No justiﬁcation is required. (6 Points) Page 11 of 21 f) (⋆ ⋆) Consider the ring Z2[x]x2+x+1[y]. Divide (x + 1)y4 + y3 + (x + 1)y2 + x by y2 + y + (x + 1) with remainders. (6 Points) Page 12 of 21 Task 4. Each correct answer gives one point. No justiﬁcation is required. (3 Points) 1.) The expression (∀x P (x)) ∨ (∃x ¬P (x)) is a mathematical statement. 2 True 2 False 2.) The following derivation rule is sound: {F, ¬F } ⊢ G. 2 True 2 False 3.) Any calculus with the following derivation rule is complete: ∅ ⊢ F . 2 True 2 False b) (⋆) Consider the formula ∃x ((∀y Q(x, y) ) → P (z) ) ∧ Q(y, x). Give an equivalent formula in prenex form. No justiﬁcation is required. (2 Points) c) (⋆) Let S = {2, 3, 5, 7, 9} and P = N \ {0, 1}. Moreover, deﬁne for all s ∈ S and all p ∈ P τ (s) = 1 def ⇐⇒ s is not prime, and ϕ(s, p) = 1 def ⇐⇒ p2 | s. Is the proof system (S, P, τ, ϕ) sound? Is it complete? Justify both of your answers. (4 Points) Page 13 of 21 d) (⋆) Mark each step that is wrong in the following derivation in the resolution calculus. (2 Points) {¬D, E} {A, ¬E} {¬B, D} {B} {¬A, B, ¬B} {A, ¬D} {¬A, B} {A, ¬B} ∅ e) (⋆) Prove or disprove: If F and G are formulas such that ¬F and F ∨ G are satisﬁable, then G is satisﬁable. (3 Points) Page 14 of 21 f) (⋆) Prove that (¬C ∧ (A → B)) ∨ C ≡ A → (B ∨ C) by using only the following rules: 1.) F → G ≡ ¬F ∨ G 2.) F ∧ F ≡ F 3.) F ∨ F ≡ F 4.) F ∧ G ≡ G ∧ F 5.) F ∨ G ≡ G ∨ F 6.) (F ∧ G) ∧ H ≡ F ∧ (G ∧ H) 7.) (F ∨ G) ∨ H ≡ F ∨ (G ∨ H) 8.) F ∧ (G ∨ H) ≡ (F ∧ G) ∨ (F ∧ H) 9.) F ∨ (G ∧ H) ≡ (F ∨ G) ∧ (F ∨ H) 10.) ¬¬F ≡ F 11.) ¬(F ∧ G) ≡ ¬F ∨ ¬G 12.) ¬(F ∨ G) ≡ ¬F ∧ ¬G 13.) F ∨ ⊤ ≡ ⊤ 14.) F ∧ ⊤ ≡ F 15.) F ∨ ⊥ ≡ F 16.) F ∧ ⊥ ≡ ⊥ 17.) F ∨ ¬F ≡ ⊤ 18.) F ∧ ¬F ≡ ⊥ In each step, syntactically apply exactly one rule and state the number of the rule you applied. Within one step, do not apply a rule multiple times. Example step: ¬A ∨ ((C ∧ B) ∨ ¬B) 7.) ≡ (¬A ∨ (C ∧ B)) ∨ ¬B.
